entries.title: Marpa v. Parse::RecDescent: a rematch
entries.text: Both will allow you to write grammars, but which is faster to run? Given a specific, simple language you can see that Marpa can be more than 100 times faster than Parse::RecDescent.

entries.title: Pre-Modern Perl VS Post-Modern Perl: FIGHT!
entries.text: Last week we saw two people complaining in blog posts about the 'modern Perl' movement. This time you can see how Buddy Burden takes on the nay-sayers barefoot! Is this a real fight? I don't think so. It is 'just' the simple tension between people who accept, and people who dislike changes.

entries.title: How Do I Keep My New Product Out Of My Employers IP
entries.text: Are you working on a code-based business idea while still employed? Do you have a contract that say 'everything you make, even what you dream at night belongs to your employer'? JT Smith recommends a way out. Without quitting your job.

entries.title: Minimum Viable Product
entries.text: .. and if you are already building a product, here is another advice from JT Smith which, IMHO goes very well with the Open Source mantra: Release early, release often.

entries.title: Being nice to colleagues with git pre-commit hooks
entries.text: The article is about test code, but this could apply to regular code as well. How many times have you added print statements or other 'debugging code' to your application? And how many times have you forgotten to remove it before committing to Git? You can avoid it using pre-commit hooks.

entries.title: RLE in Perl5
entries.text: Tokuhiro Matsuno show how to do Run-length encoding in Perl 5. Short, to the point.

entries.title: TPF Devel::Cover grant report May 2013
entries.text: I really appreciate the work Paul Johnson does with Devel::Cover. I just don't understand why does The Perl Foundation not post these reports on their site as they do with the other two major grants.

entries.title: Dancers Just Wanna Have Fonts
entries.text: Yanick Champoux refuses to use plain fonts, but allows us to download only letters we actually need to view the title of his site. How can he do both, and how does he do it with Dancer?

entries.title: Server-side security war games: Part 0
entries.text: Mike Doherty has a series of articles that can help you think on how to secure your web site. This is the link to the first article, you'll will have to browse around a bit to find the rest but they can be useful, even if not Perl specific. In the latest one you could learn how to log in to a web application without providing a password.

entries.title: Catalyst 5.9004x "SicilianButtercup" Release Retrospective
entries.text: If you are using Catalyst, it can be very important to see what's going on among the core developers, even if you don't currently have the time to contribute or follow the development more closely. John Napiorkowski makes it easy with his writings.

entries.title: Thanking the Open Source developers in the Catalyst Ecosystem
